text: For a long time

text: what I wanted to do more than anything else was to get poems shorter and shorter and shorter and then I discovered I was too successful. I stopped writing completely.

text: This is the newest poem I have written

text: It's= uh

text: it's a poem which I wrestled with for a long time and put away untouched, and then I was asked very recently if I would contribute to a book intended primarily for children
speaker: Subject

text: And this sent me back to this poem again

text: which is a fairy tale poem

text: Those of you who know me at all know that one of the overwhelming interests of my life is fairy tales
speaker: Subject

text: and for many years, I tried to turn my favorite horrific fairy tale, which is called the Juniper Tree into verse, I was totally unsuccessful at doing this

text: And I've ended up doing a b- # a= a fairy from an altogether different tradition

text: I'm happy that I have some Japanese friends in the audience tonight

text: because this poem is in fact

text: a poem based on an old Japanese fairy tale which is called Momotaro

text: or the Peach Boy

text: I don't know whether any of you here
speaker: Subject

text: know it
speaker: Subject

text: or many of you here know it

text: but it is a poem which always deeply moved me.

text: Once many years ago, I was set to learning Japanese
speaker: Subject

text: under the auspices of the United States Navy, as a matter of fact, and the only thing I read
speaker: Subject

text: of all the material that we went through in the process of learning Japanese that ever stayed in my head was this story.
speaker: Subject

text: I could still hear it going in my head for instance The noise that the peach out of which the little boy comes makes as it turns over and over in the river, donburi, donburi, donburi.
speaker: Subject

text: I can hear the boy's mother talking to him as she loads him up with kibi dango millet seed cakes, the best kibi dango in all Japan,
speaker: Subject

text: and I can hear the animals who stopped him,
speaker: Subject

text: I've forgotten all the military Japanese I ever knew. I can't tell you the word for a battleship or a gun

text: or an ((emplacement)) or anything else but I can t- # probably tell you this story in Japanese though all the rest of it is departed from me. And I'd wanted to work it and rework it, and I've tried=

text: And it finally occurred to me as I under- # with this ((sic-)) # you see it's= a= it's a long # it's only one poem I'm going to read so I have an excuse for a long introduction, right?

text: uh As I thought about the ((uh)) appropriate form for this poem, I decided I would return to a very ancient and honorable form, very flexible

text: and very beautiful doggerel

text: This is a poem which is written in doggerel. I dearly love a rhyme, I'll do anything in the world for a rhyme and I don't much care how fast or how slow
speaker: Subject

text: I get to it in the line.

text: The interesting thing which happened to this story which originally had a happy ending
speaker: Subject

text: Peach Boy goes out and he goes to the Onigashima, the island of the devils, and he conquers the king of the demons, devils, whatever you call them, monsters
speaker: Subject

text: and he comes back home makes his family happy and he lives happily ever after. But as I wrote this poem, I discovered that the ending of it insisted on changing and I couldn't finish it until I changed the ending
speaker: Subject

text: And this finally turned out then to be a poem not only about what I always thought it was about, which is the impossibility of finding a proper name for everything,
speaker: Subject

text: anything, this is a poem about naming.
speaker: Subject

text: But it also turned out to be a poem about heroism,
speaker: Subject

text: an antiheroic poem
speaker: Subject

text: And I suppose the reason it became an antiheroic poem is because the language which I learned reading the story of the little Peach Boy, I ended up using on the island of Iwo Jima
speaker: Subject

text: and too many bad connotations are connected with it. Anyhow, I think all children always know that the so called happy endings of fairy tales are lies.
speaker: Subject

text: Right?
speaker: Subject

text: But they understand that we're courteous enough to lie to them and pretend that we think they believe in us when we tell them that everybody lived happily ever after. You'll see nobody lives happily ever after in this.
speaker: Subject

text: ((It's)) divided into sections which are the parts of the story. The first part of Momotaro or the Peach Boy then is called The Finding of the Peach
speaker: Subject

text: An old woodchopper
speaker: Subject

text: and his old, old wife lived in the forest for all of their life, and the name of the chopper was Chopper.
speaker: Subject

text: And the name of his wife was Wife and the name of the days they lived was Day and the name of the nights was Night
speaker: Subject

text: But the name of the sum of them all was Pain for they had borne no child to bear their name
speaker: Subject

text: Until crouched one day by the bank of the stream
speaker: Subject

text: washing her wash and dreaming her dream, the old woman saw a giant peach afloat on the water just out of her reach
speaker: Subject

text: Over and over it turned and the sun singing a song or humming a hum, donburi donburi reach out your hand, what is borne in the water may live on the land, what begins as a peach may end as a man, so wet your feet
speaker: Subject

text: and catch what you can
speaker: Subject

text: Like a child, she clutched it, clutched at the peach, something to fondle
speaker: Subject

text: or something to eat like a child she held it tight to her breast
speaker: Subject

text: but knowing no names how should ((she+)) guess what to call it or what would come next. Peach, she called it
speaker: Subject

text: carrying it home
speaker: Subject

text: to where the old man
speaker: Subject

text: waited alone
speaker: Subject

text: Part two is called The Cutting of the Peach.
speaker: Subject

text: I'll cut it, said the old man
speaker: Subject

text: since cutting was his trade
speaker: Subject

text: Let's eat what luck has brought us, why should we be afraid? But his wife was lost in wonder and talk, though not her trade was what she did
speaker: Subject

text: when she was not hanging in a glade their wash or the wash of others or mending what was frayed
speaker: Subject

text: Hold off, she cried, or let me who've held it to my breast draw the knife across its skin, as soft as a caress
